title: you tell when someone is lying?
intro: Do you know when someone is lying to you? Are all lies bad? Could they be a way to preserve society? Sam and Rob discuss the social benefits of lying and teach you some vocabulary. Honestly.
this_week_question: A competition is held in Cumbria in the UK every year to find and award the title of "The Biggest Liar in the World". But which type of people are not allowed to take part?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: small lie, told to avoid upsetting someone
try to hide something by tricking people to gain an advantage
a term used in psychology to describe the time taken between a stimulus or question and a response to it

transcript.text: Note: This is not a word for word transcript

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English. I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: And I'm Sam.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: In this programme, we’re talking about biscuits.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Really? That’s not what I was told… oh hold on, you’re lying.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, you’re right, Sam. I am lying simply to demonstrate our topic – lying and how to detect it. You detected my lie very easily, Sam!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I could tell by the smirk on your face that you were telling a fib – that’s the word for a small, inoffensive lie.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: To be honest, talking about lie detecting will be much more interesting than biscuits. But first, let’s start with a question for you to answer. A competition is held in Cumbria in the UK every year to find and award the title of "The Biggest Liar in the World". But which type of people are not allowed to take part?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I’d be lying if I said I knew – but based on personal experience I’d say estate agents – they’d find it too easy!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ha – well that’s your opinion but I’ll let you know if you’re right at the end of the programme. So, lying is something I’m sure a lot of us do – sometimes to avoid trouble, sometimes to cheat people, or sometimes just to impress someone – did you know I can speak seven languages, Sam?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: That’s just a barefaced lie, Rob! But I can see how easy lying can be, and that’s what neuroscientist Sophie Scott thinks. Here she is on BBC Radio 4’s ‘Seriously’ podcast, explaining how we sometimes lie just to be nice!

transcript.author: Sophie Scott, neuroscientist
transcript.text: Often what we mean by lying is someone setting out to deceive us with their words or their actions but actually normal conversation probably can only happen because we don’t actually say all the time exactly what we really think and what we really mean. And that kind of cooperation is at the heart , I think, of a lot of social interactions for humans and I think that’s one of the strong pushes to make conversation polite and therefore frequently not actually truthful.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So Sophie mentions two types of lying. There’s the one when we try to deceive someone – so that’s trying to hide something by tricking someone to gain an advantage.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Hmm, that’s like you getting me to pay £10 for a cinema ticket when actually they were only £5. That’s just dishonest, but there are also what I like to call white lies – small lies we tell to avoid upsetting someone. Those are lies that aren’t intended to give you an advantage.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, Sophie Scott says we use them in normal conversation – when we don’t say what we really mean.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: So, we want to make conversation polite because we want to cooperate with each other – she says cooperation is at the heart . Something that’s at the heart is the most important or essential part.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Now telling lies is one thing but how do you know if we’re being lied to?  Sometimes there are telltale signs, such as someone’s face turning red or someone shuffling their feet.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: But if you really want to know if someone is lying, maybe we should listen to Richard Wiseman, a psychologist at the University of Hertfordshire. Here he is speaking on the ‘Seriously’ podcast…

transcript.author: Richard Wiseman, psychologist, University of Hertfordshire
transcript.text: Liars in general say less. They tend to have a longer what's called response latency , which is the time between the end of the question and the beginning of the answer. And there also tends to be an emotional distance in the lie – so the words ‘me’,’my’, ‘I’ – all those things tend to drop away in lies and it’s much much harder for liars to control what they’re saying and how they’re saying it, so focus your attention there, you become a better lie detector.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Some good advice from Richard Wiseman. So to detect lies we need to listen out for the response latency – a term used in psychology to describe the time taken between a stimulus or question and a response to it. The bigger the gap, the more chance there is that someone is lying. Is that a good summary, Sam?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Sort of, Rob. Richard also suggests we focus on – or concentrate on – what and how people are saying things too. There’s probably more to it than just that.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well now you know how to detect my lies, Sam, maybe honestly is the best policy – as they say. So I’m now going to give you an honest answer to the question I asked earlier. A competition is held in Cumbria, in the UK, every year to award the title of "The Biggest Liar in the World". But which type of people are not allowed to take part?

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: I guessed c) estate agents.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And you are wrong, I’m afraid. Lawyers, as well as politicians, are not allowed to enter the competition. It’s claimed "they are judged to be too skilled at telling porkies " – porkies is an informal word for ‘pork pies’ and that rhymes with ‘lies’.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Fascinating stuff, Rob and that’s no lie! But now, shall we recap some of the vocabulary we’ve heard today?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Why not? A fib is a small inoffensive lie .

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: A white lie is also a small lie, told to avoid upsetting someone.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: When you deceive someone, you try to hide something by tricking them to gain an advantage.

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: When something is at the heart of something, it is the most important or essential part of it. And we heard about response latency – a term used in psychology to describe the time taken between a stimulus or question and a response to it.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, thank you, Sam. That’s all from 6 Minute English. We look forward to your company next time. Goodbye!

transcript.author: Sam
transcript.text: Bye everyone!

authors: Richard Wiseman, psychologist, University of Hertfordshire
